content.description:
Classic. Start by two yellow blazes and climb holds and the arête to a fun topout. The rock on this is perfect, maybe among the best granite in New Hampshire.  

  Since the trail passes right through these boulders, I wouldnt be surprised if some intrepid hiker nabbed the FA of Yellow Blazes.
content.location: Just right of the trail as it passes between the boulders.

content.description: Many variations are possible on this slab. The best variation is on the far left side, at a point where you can actually place a crashpad below.
content.location: This is the left wall of the corridor, as you're heading uphill. Opposite of Yellow Blazes.

content.description: Start with your right hand on an edge and your left hand around the corner. Slap to the lip, move left, and top out. Try to avoid grabbing the tree roots.
content.location: This is the rightmost problem on the backside of the Corridor Boulders.

content.description: This is the striking s-shaped corner feature in the middle of the face. Sit start, and climb the corner to a crux just before the lip. The landing is bad.
content.location: The feature up the center of the backside of the Corridor Boulders.

content.description:
You could walk past this line a hundred times and not notice it. This problem is not tall, but it's fierce. 

  We thought this was a project until we heard that Bobby Hardage climbed this circa 1998/2000. I believe he started sitting and he kept both hands on the arete and worked to the top that way.   

  Another possible variation is to start with your left hand on the corner and your right hand on an edge in the red streak. Then, climb the face by slapping your left hand up the corner. I'm not sure if this variation has been done.  

  The grade is just an estimate and could be off +/- 3 V points.
content.location: Walk uphill through the corridor. As soon as you exit the corridor, look to the left. There it is.

content.description: Climb the face just right of Yellow Blazes. A hard pull gets you onto the face.

Climb the obvious layback crack located in the "corridor". Fun laybacking with the crux coming at the top. 

  This gets the PG-13 rating because a fall from the crux could send you crashing into the walls behind you. Also the corridor is narrow so a crash pad is hard to put down. Good climbing though!
content.location: Walk past Yellow Blazes and into the corridor. this is located on the right when the corridor makes a sharp left.

content.description: The left most line on the back face of the boulder. Start with both your hands and your left heel on an obvious shelf. Reach up to crimps, use the right arête, and throw to the lip. A great little problem.
content.location: This is the leftmost of a bunch of lines on the backside of the Corridor Boulders.

content.description: Obvious layback crack in the middle of the face. A sit start, involving grovelly jams in a flare, is possible for the displaced trad climber.
This is one of the most concentrated spots in the area and it consists of three boulders very close to each other. The trail follows the corridor right through the center of the boulders.
